content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the Act. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" authorizes an FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions based on estimated compact migrant expenditures submitted by the chief executive official. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts the estimation before submitting it to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts the estimated compact migrant expenditures before submitting them to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for FMAP increase calculations under the "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016." The Secretary of Health and Human Services notifies affected jurisdictions of FMAP increases under the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016, ensuring payments do not exceed set limitations. Chief executive officials must report migrant expenditures for reconciliation and payment adjustments. The chief executive official of affected jurisdictions must submit migrant expenditure reports to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will then assess if FMAP increases resulted in higher federal payments to the jurisdictions. Adjustments to the FMAP for future quarters will be made to account for any overpayment or underpayment. The FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions is limited to 100 percent. Compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Definitions for affected jurisdiction and compact migrant expenditures are provided in this section. The Social Security Act is amended to include a conforming amendment related to non-Federal funds expended by affected jurisdictions for services under the Act. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendments are made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include educating alien children from the Freely Associated States and providing payments for eligible federally connected children who are citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. Amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 include providing additional funding for eligible federally connected children from the Freely Associated States. $10,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for this purpose. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act to give preference to U.S. citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the U.S. and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State will seek an agreement with an organization to assess the strategic importance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, including their role in the Asia-Pacific region and the administration of the Compacts of Free Association. The eligible organization will assess the strategic importance of the US relationship with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, including recommendations for improvements and future administration of Compacts and financial support. A report must be submitted to the Secretary of State within one year, detailing the assessment and recommendations. The eligible organization will submit a report to the Secretary of State containing an assessment, required matters, and any additional relevant information. The report will be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex if needed. The organization can obtain necessary information directly from US departments or agencies upon request.
